E(X) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} (2\lambda_i + 1) |c_i|^2

Given a smooth vector field $X$ on $M$ with divergence $\text{div}_g(X) = 0$, we can express $X$ in terms of the orthonormal basis of eigenfunctions $\{ \phi_i \}$ corresponding to the eigenvalues $\lambda_i$ as:
$$
X = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} c_i \phi_i
$$
where $c_i = \langle X, \phi_i \rangle$ are the coefficients.

Now, let's calculate the energy functional $E(X)$:
\begin{align*}
E(X) &= \int_M \| X \|^2_g \, d\text{vol}_g \\
&= \int_M \langle X, X \rangle_g \, d\text{vol}_g \\
&= \int_M \left\langle \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} c_i \phi_i, \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} c_j \phi_j \right\rangle_g \, d\text{vol}_g \\
&= \int_M \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} c_i c_j \langle \phi_i, \phi_j \rangle_g \, d\text{vol}_g \\
&= \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} c_i c_j \int_M \langle \phi_i, \phi_j \rangle_g \, d\text{vol}_g \\
&= \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{\infty} c_i c_j \delta_{ij} \\
&= \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |c_i|^2
\end{align*}

Here, we used the orthonormality of the eigenfunctions $\{ \phi_i \}$, i.e., $\langle \phi_i, \phi_j \rangle_g = \delta_{ij}$.

Since the Laplace-Beltrami operator $-\Delta_g$ is self-adjoint, the eigenvalues $\lambda_i$ are real and the eigenfunctions $\phi_i$ form an orthonormal basis. The eigenfunctions also satisfy $-\Delta_g \phi_i = \lambda_i \phi_i$.

$$
E(X) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} |c_i|^2 = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} (2\lambda_i + 1) |c_i|^2
